Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Ionic Liquids in Sample Preparation and Multidimensional Chromatographic Separations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Jared L. Anderson of the University of Toledo is supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program in the Division of Chemistry to explore the application of ionic liquids as separation media in chromatography and microextractions. The project will provide new knowledge on how ionic liquids effect the differential extraction of analytes and their separation and analysis by various chromatographic techniques, and will expand the scope of applicability of ionic liquids in the analysis of real chemical and biological samples. A major impact across fields other than analytical chemistry is in the development of techniques for the analysis of complex fluids such as oils and fuels derived from biomass.

Professor Anderson and his research team will conduct three separate initiatives under the umbrella of ionic liquids in separation science. Magnetic ionic liquids will be studied in the selective extraction and long term storage of deoxyribonucleic acid; polymeric ionic liquids, incorporating single-walled carbon nanotubes, will be developed and used as sorbent coatings for solid-phase microextraction; and ionic liquids will be developed and used as selective stationary phases for multidimensional gas chromatography.

In the course of conducting this research, graduate and undergraduate students will acquire valuable skills in separation science and chromatography, and Facebook-based social networking outreach programs will be developed to present scientific concepts to young children and the general public.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding from this grant was used to understand the use of ionic liquid-based materials in the broad field of separation science. The ionic liquid-based materials examined in this work include room temperature ionic liquids (IL), polymeric ionic liquids (PIL), and magnetic ionic liquids (MIL).  Three ultimate areas were explored within this project and include (1) the study of PILs as extraction materials in solid-phase microextraction (SPME); (2) the examination of MILs as novel materials for the extraction and storage of nucleic acids from biological matrices of varied complexity; and (3) the use of IL and PIL-based materials as high temperature and high selectivity stationary phases in comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography. In the first objective, the SPME technique was improved by developing new extraction materials that permit the trace-level determination of molecules from complex samples. New classes of PIL materials were examined and a systematic study was undertaken to understand the role of how molecular interactions are affected when PILs are used in the presence of complex samples, such as coffee. In addition, PIL-based materials incorporating carbon nanotubes were examined and a platform was designed to permit the understanding of molecule-carbon nanotube interactions. In the second part of this proposed work, magnetic ionic liquids were examined and more was understood regarding their fundamental properties. MILs are paramagnetic liquids that are composed of at least one paramagnetic metal. New classes of hydrophobic, low viscosity MILs incorporating metals with high magnetic susceptibility were produced and were shown to be readily manipulated using moderate strength magnetic fields. These MIL solvents were used in analytical microextractions to isolate DNA and to facilitate its downstream detection and analysis in polymerase chain reaction (PCR). MILs were also studied in other extraction techniques and were shown to be highly versatile solvents in headspace and vacuum single drop microextraction. Ion-tagged oligonucleotides (ITOs) were synthesized in high yield using thiolene ?click? chemistry and were coupled with MILs. The ITOs were capable of annealing to target DNA and could be subsequently captured by the MIL solvent to facilitate downstream analysis. This approach constitutes the first particle-free method for the analysis of DNA and could have widespread utility in microfluidic applications. Hydrophobic MILs based on nickel(II) and cobalt(II) metals were shown to be selective in the extraction of E. Coli cells; subsequent studies demonstrated that the MILs did not dramatically damage the cells indicating that this approach could have widespread utility in bacterial analysis. In the third objective, new ionic liquid-based stationary phases were developed and tested in comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography. For dicationic ionic liquids, the length of linker chain and free alkyl groups were shown to produce stationary phase materials that exhibited lower melting points and provided better separation of aliphatic molecules from kerosene and diesel samples compared to smaller dicationic liquids. Lipidic ionic liquids were examined as stationary phases and it was revealed that the enhanced dispersive-type interactions provided better separation of aliphatic hydrocarbons. A new class of silver-based ionic liquids were synthesized and used as one-dimensional stationary phases for the separation of alkenes and alkynes from paraffins. It was shown that the complexation behavior of the silver-based ionic liquid permitted its stable coating on the wall of the capillary column, with thermal stabilities up to approximately 160 degrees C. The silver-alkyne interactions were shown to be very strong as evidenced by these analytes not eluting from the capillary column. These materials were shown to exhibit high selectivity in the separation of alkenes from alkanes. In this project, young scientists were trained in all aspects of chemical analysis, including chemical separations, bioanalytical chemistry, and mass spectrometry. High school students were actively recruited and participated in the American Chemical Society Project SEED program for 8 weeks during the summer for each year of the grant. Undergraduate students were actively involved in this work along with their graduate students mentors. Graduate students took an active role in writing scientific manuscripts.  Both undergraduate and graduate students presented their results at local, national and international conferences. Videos were recorded of young scientists discussing their research projects and were posted on YouTube and Facebook for broad community viewership.

 


Last Modified: 11/04/2018
Modified by: Jared L Anderson
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Funding from this grant was used to understand the use of ionic liquid-based materials in the broad field of separation science. The ionic liquid-based materials examined in this work include room temperature ionic liquids (IL), polymeric ionic liquids (PIL), and magnetic ionic liquids (MIL). Three ultimate areas were explored within this project and include (1) the study of PILs as extraction materials in solid-phase microextraction (SPME); (2) the examination of MILs as novel materials for the extraction and storage of nucleic acids from biological matrices of varied complexity; and (3) the use of IL and PIL-based materials as high temperature and high selectivity stationary phases in comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography. In the first objective, the SPME technique was improved by developing new extraction materials that permit the trace-level determination of molecules from complex samples. New classes of PIL materials were examined and a systematic study was undertaken to understand the role of how molecular interactions are affected when PILs are used in the presence of complex samples, such as coffee. MILs are paramagnetic liquids that are composed of at least one paramagnetic metal. Videos were recorded of young scientists discussing their research projects and were posted on YouTube and Facebook for broad community viewership.
